title: How to Convince Your Friend to Trust You Again

steps.title: Respect any requests for space.
steps.content: Respect any requests for space. If you've hurt your friend, they may not want to immediately spend time with you. They may want some space initially. It's important to respect this if you want to eventually win your friend back over. [2] X Research source Be understanding. If you hurt your friend, they may not be able to forgive immediately. Do not take it personally if your friend asks you to limit contact with them temporarily. The space can be valuable for both of you. Your friend can have a chance to cool down, and you can take the opportunity to reflect on what you did.

steps.title: Reflect on your friend's needs.
steps.content: Reflect on your friend's needs. You will eventually want to apologize to your friend. [3] X Expert Source Rebecca Tenzer, MAT, MA, LCSW, CCTP, CGCS, CCATP, CCFP Clinical Therapist & Adjunct Professor Expert Interview. 2 October 2020. The most effective apologies focus on acknowledging the needs and feelings of those you've hurt. Spend the time to yourself reflecting on what your friend might need from you. [4] X Research source Be completely open and honest about what happened. [5] X Expert Source Rebecca Tenzer, MAT, MA, LCSW, CCTP, CGCS, CCATP, CCFP Clinical Therapist & Adjunct Professor Expert Interview. 2 October 2020. Did you violate your friend's emotional needs? This may be how you lost their trust. For example, maybe you made a comment about your friend's weight. This is a sensitive topic for them, and they reacted poorly. What does your friend need from you to move forward? They probably need you to be more respectful and understanding in the future. They may also need you to understand which subjects are off limits for jokes.

steps.title: Gain an understanding of your behavior.
steps.content: Gain an understanding of your behavior. It may help to understand why you behaved the way you did. If you did something to hurt your friend, there may be a reason for this. Spend some time reflecting on any factors that contributed to your behavior. Ask yourself honestly why you lashed out. Were you feeling insecure or bad about yourself? Many people hurt others due to their own feelings on inadequacy. Once you understand your behavior better, think about how to change in the future. Maybe you lashed out at your friend because you have issues with your own weight. You could talk to a therapist about your body issues and try to treat your body better through healthy eating and exercise.

steps.title: Write a letter.
steps.content: Write a letter. You can send this letter, if you want. You can also simply write it as a means to get your feelings out. When you apologize to your friend, having written out your thoughts may be helpful. [6] X Research source Write a sincere letter expressing your remorse. Begin with something like, "I'm really sorry that I hurt you." You can try to offer an explanation; however, make it clear it's an explanation and not an excuse . You do not want to sound like you're justifying your behavior. You can send the letter out to your friend. You can also type the letter and email it. You can request to meet in person to apologize formally.

steps.title: Acknowledge your mistake and apologize.
steps.content: Acknowledge your mistake and apologize. The first step of a solid apology are the words, "I'm sorry." People need to hear this first. From there, acknowledge your mistakes. You want to make it clear you understand what you did wrong. [7] X Research source For example, begin with something like, "I'm sorry. I completely take responsibility for messing up and hurting you." From there, explain what you did and why it was wrong. For example, "I never should have made that comment about your weight. It wasn't funny. It was insensitive and hurtful."

steps.title: Express regret.
steps.content: Express regret. Your friend will be more inclined to listen to your apology if you seem genuinely remorseful. Be direct about how bad you feel about your actions. [8] X Research source This can be short and simple. For example, "I really regret being cruel and breaking your trust."

steps.title: Empathize with your friend.
steps.content: Empathize with your friend. You want to make it clear you understand. Your friend is more likely to trust you in the future if she feels you understand the consequences of your actions. Your friend will want to know you've learned your lesson and will not screw up again. [9] X Research source You can say something like, "I can't imagine how hurt you must have been when you heard what I said." From there, once again take responsibility. For example, "I am so sorry I hurt you in this way, and put you all in a position where you felt betrayed. There's no excuse for my behavior." Be willing to allow your friend to express how you hurt them. After an apology, your friend who was hurt may restate how it affected them as a way of making sure you truly understand how they feel. Be prepared for this: listen, try to understand, and, even if you have already said "I'm sorry," you may have to say it again. [10] X Expert Source Rebecca Tenzer, MAT, MA, LCSW, CCTP, CGCS, CCATP, CCFP Clinical Therapist & Adjunct Professor Expert Interview. 2 October 2020.

steps.title: Request forgiveness.
steps.content: Request forgiveness. You want to end things on a good note, so ask your friend to give you a second chance. Things may not be normal again right away, and your friend may initially reject your apology; however, leave the door open for reestablishing trust in the future. [11] X Research source Your request for forgiveness doesn't have to be long. You can simply say something like, "I'm sorry for having hurt you. I know it may take time, but I hope in the future we can be friends again."

steps.title: Offer restitution.
steps.content: Offer restitution. If you broke trust, your friend may expect you to make up for it in some way. You can offer a concrete means of repairing the damage when you apologize. [12] X Research source Let your friend know if you have already done anything to make up for it. For example, "I made you this mix CD of apology songs, and I've been seeing a counselor about my own body image issues." You can also tell your friend what you may do in the future to repair things. Make sure your friend knows this will never happen again. For example, "I'm really making my own mental health a priority right now. I'm not going to stop seeing a counselor until I feel stable enough not to lash out at others."

steps.title: Ask your friend what you can do.
steps.content: Ask your friend what you can do. Your friend may set some boundaries with you and let you know what they will and will not accept in a friendship. They may also have some ideas about how you can begin retraining their trust. You can say something like, "I know it's hard for you to trust me right now. Is there anything I can do to show you I really mean it? Is there something I can do to begin earning your trust back?" They may have some specific steps you need to take in order to feel you can be trusted again, depending on what happened. For instance, if you friend found out you were talking about them behind their back, they may want you to go speak with those people and tell them what you said was untrue, and that you were wrong to say those things to them.

steps.title: Be there for your friend.
steps.content: Be there for your friend. Show your friend you're capable of loyalty. If they let you back into their life, work on being a good friend. You want to make sure you do not break their trust again. [13] X Research source Be sensitive to your friend's worries and fears. Ask your friend how they're doing if they are going through a rough time. Offer to listen if they need to vent. Never judge your friend. If they express something, react with respect and interest. People are likely to trust those who do not tell them what to do.

steps.title: Allow your friend to be angry at times.
steps.content: Allow your friend to be angry at times. It's going to take time to reestablish trust. In the aftermath of an apology, do not be surprised if your friend is still mad. They may still be stung by what you did, and it make take some time for them to work through that. Continually put yourself in your friend's shoes. If you feel frustrated by their inability to forgive you, think about how hurt you would be in their position.

steps.title: Demonstrate you've changed through your actions.
steps.content: Demonstrate you've changed through your actions. Actions often speak louder than words. After apologizing, try to show your friend how you have changed. [14] X Research source Work on being a more trustworthy person. Keep your promises, do not talk behind people's backs, and be there for your friend emotionally.

steps.title: Have patience.
steps.content: Have patience. You can rebuild broken trust over time. [15] X Expert Source Rebecca Tenzer, MAT, MA, LCSW, CCTP, CGCS, CCATP, CCFP Clinical Therapist & Adjunct Professor Expert Interview. 2 October 2020. Be consistent and kind with your actions. Eventually, your friend should forgive you; however, do not expect this to happen overnight. It is difficult to trust people, and when trust is broken it can be tough to get it back. It may take many months before your friend completely forgives you.
